annotation.spannedText: If an infant did not receive the birth dose within the 1st 7 days of life, catch-up of that dose is not necessary

classMention.mentionClass: If an infant did not receive the birth dose within the 1st 7 days of life, catch-up of that dose is not necessary

annotation.spannedText: Such infants then only require 3 doses of a hepatitis B-containing vaccine, given at 2, 4 and 6 months of age

classMention.mentionClass: Such infants then only require 3 doses of a hepatitis B-containing vaccine, given at 2, 4 and 6 months of age

annotation.spannedText: A 3-dose schedule at birth, 1–2 months and 6–18 months of age has been shown to be equally as immunogenic as the recommended Australian schedule above; such schedules are often used overseas

classMention.mentionClass: A 3-dose schedule at birth, 1–2 months and 6–18 months of age has been shown to be equally as immunogenic as the recommended Australian schedule above; such schedules are often used overseas

annotation.spannedText: 30-32 Children born overseas who have received hepatitis B vaccine in such a 3-dose schedule can also be considered to have completed the primary vaccination course

classMention.mentionClass: 30-32 Children born overseas who have received hepatitis B vaccine in such a 3-dose schedule can also be considered to have completed the primary vaccination course

annotation.spannedText: For infants, the final dose of the primary hepatitis B vaccine course should preferably be administered at ≥24 weeks of age

classMention.mentionClass: For infants, the final dose of the primary hepatitis B vaccine course should preferably be administered at ≥24 weeks of age

annotation.spannedText: However, if the final dose is given at <24 weeks but ≥16 weeks of age, it is not necessary to repeat the dose, provided the minimum intervals between doses in Table 2.1.7 (in 2.1.5ï¿½Catch-up.) have been met

classMention.mentionClass: However, if the final dose is given at <24 weeks but ≥16 weeks of age, it is not necessary to repeat the dose, provided the minimum intervals between doses in Table 2.1.7 (in 2.1.5ï¿½Catch-up.) have been met

annotation.spannedText: The minimum intervals outlined above should be met where possible

classMention.mentionClass: The minimum intervals outlined above should be met where possible

annotation.spannedText: The majority of individuals in whom anti-HBs becomes undetectable have been shown to mount an anamnestic response to an additional vaccine dose, which indicates they are likely to be protected if exposed to hepatitis B virus

classMention.mentionClass: The majority of individuals in whom anti-HBs becomes undetectable have been shown to mount an anamnestic response to an additional vaccine dose, which indicates they are likely to be protected if exposed to hepatitis B virus

annotation.spannedText: Accelerated schedules should only be used for those persons with an imminent risk of exposure, such as those intending to travel to hepatitis B endemic areas with a very limited time before departure

classMention.mentionClass: Accelerated schedules should only be used for those persons with an imminent risk of exposure, such as those intending to travel to hepatitis B endemic areas with a very limited time before departure

annotation.spannedText: Three-dose schedules for adults and children aged <16 years are acceptable; however, a 2-dose schedule in children 1–15 years of age, using Twinrix (720/20), also results in protective antibody levels for both hepatitis A and hepatitis B

classMention.mentionClass: Three-dose schedules for adults and children aged <16 years are acceptable; however, a 2-dose schedule in children 1–15 years of age, using Twinrix (720/20), also results in protective antibody levels for both hepatitis A and hepatitis B

annotation.spannedText: Reconstituted vaccine should be used as soon as practicable

classMention.mentionClass: Reconstituted vaccine should be used as soon as practicable

annotation.spannedText: Infanrix hexa must be reconstituted by adding the entire contents of the syringe to the vial and shaking until the pellet is completely dissolved

classMention.mentionClass: Infanrix hexa must be reconstituted by adding the entire contents of the syringe to the vial and shaking until the pellet is completely dissolved

annotation.spannedText: The birth dose should be given as soon as the baby is medically stable, and preferably within 24 hours of birth

classMention.mentionClass: The birth dose should be given as soon as the baby is medically stable, and preferably within 24 hours of birth

annotation.spannedText: The rationale for recommending the birth dose for all newborn infants is not only to prevent vertical transmission from a mother with chronic hepatitis B infection (recognising that there may be errors or delays in maternal testing, reporting, communication or appropriate response), but also to prevent horizontal transmission to the infant in the first months of life from persons with chronic hepatitis B infection who are household or other close contacts

classMention.mentionClass: The rationale for recommending the birth dose for all newborn infants is not only to prevent vertical transmission from a mother with chronic hepatitis B infection (recognising that there may be errors or delays in maternal testing, reporting, communication or appropriate response), but also to prevent horizontal transmission to the infant in the first months of life from persons with chronic hepatitis B infection who are household or other close contacts

annotation.spannedText: Every effort should be made to administer the vaccine before discharge from the obstetric hospital or delivery unit

classMention.mentionClass: Every effort should be made to administer the vaccine before discharge from the obstetric hospital or delivery unit

annotation.spannedText: All newborns of mothers known to have chronic hepatitis B infection must be given a birth dose of hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) (refer to ‘Management of infants born to mothers who are HBsAg-positive’ below)

classMention.mentionClass: All newborns of mothers known to have chronic hepatitis B infection must be given a birth dose of hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) (refer to ‘Management of infants born to mothers who are HBsAg-positive’ below)

annotation.spannedText: Routine antenatal screening of pregnant women for HBsAg is recommended to enable appropriate management to prevent newborn infants developing HBV infection

classMention.mentionClass: Routine antenatal screening of pregnant women for HBsAg is recommended to enable appropriate management to prevent newborn infants developing HBV infection

annotation.spannedText: Infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers should be given HBIG and a dose of monovalent hepatitis B vaccine on the day of birth, concurrently but in separate thighs. The dose of HBIG is 100 IU, to be given by IM injection

classMention.mentionClass: Infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers should be given HBIG and a dose of monovalent hepatitis B vaccine on the day of birth, concurrently but in separate thighs. The dose of HBIG is 100 IU, to be given by IM injection

annotation.spannedText: It is preferable to administer HBIG immediately after birth (preferably within 12 hours of birth and certainly within 48 hours) as its efficacy decreases markedly if given more than 48 hours after birth

classMention.mentionClass: It is preferable to administer HBIG immediately after birth (preferably within 12 hours of birth and certainly within 48 hours) as its efficacy decreases markedly if given more than 48 hours after birth

annotation.spannedText: The dose of monovalent hepatitis B vaccine should be given to the infant preferably within 24 hours of birth, and definitely within 7 days

classMention.mentionClass: The dose of monovalent hepatitis B vaccine should be given to the infant preferably within 24 hours of birth, and definitely within 7 days

annotation.spannedText: Vaccination should not be delayed beyond 7 days after birth, as vaccination alone has been shown to be reasonably effective in preventing infection, provided it is given early

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccination should not be delayed beyond 7 days after birth, as vaccination alone has been shown to be reasonably effective in preventing infection, provided it is given early

annotation.spannedText: Three subsequent doses of a hepatitis B-containing vaccine should be given, at 2, 4 and 6 months of age, so that the infant receives a total of 4 doses of hepatitis B-containing vaccines

classMention.mentionClass: Three subsequent doses of a hepatitis B-containing vaccine should be given, at 2, 4 and 6 months of age, so that the infant receives a total of 4 doses of hepatitis B-containing vaccines

annotation.spannedText: Anti-HBs antibody and HBsAg levels should be measured in infants born to mothers with chronic hepatitis B infection 3 to 12 months after completing the primary vaccine course

classMention.mentionClass: Anti-HBs antibody and HBsAg levels should be measured in infants born to mothers with chronic hepatitis B infection 3 to 12 months after completing the primary vaccine course

annotation.spannedText: Testing should not be performed before 9 months of age to avoid detection of anti-HBs antibodies from HBIG given at birth

classMention.mentionClass: Testing should not be performed before 9 months of age to avoid detection of anti-HBs antibodies from HBIG given at birth

annotation.spannedText: If the anti-HBs level is <10 mIU/mL, expert advice regarding revaccination and/or further testing should be sought

classMention.mentionClass: If the anti-HBs level is <10 mIU/mL, expert advice regarding revaccination and/or further testing should be sought

annotation.spannedText: HIV-positive children should receive 3 doses of hepatitis B vaccine using an adult formulation

classMention.mentionClass: HIV-positive children should receive 3 doses of hepatitis B vaccine using an adult formulation

annotation.spannedText: vaccination of all children and adolescents should be encouraged

classMention.mentionClass: vaccination of all children and adolescents should be encouraged

annotation.spannedText: Adolescents who did not receive an age-appropriate completed course of vaccination should be identified and offered catch-up vaccination, particularly if they fall into one of the risk categories for hepatitis B infection, discussed under ‘Adults’ below

classMention.mentionClass: Adolescents who did not receive an age-appropriate completed course of vaccination should be identified and offered catch-up vaccination, particularly if they fall into one of the risk categories for hepatitis B infection, discussed under ‘Adults’ below

annotation.spannedText: Susceptible sexual partners of persons who are HBsAg-positive should be offered post-exposure HBIG and hepatitis B vaccination; both should be initiated within 14 days of the last sexual contact

classMention.mentionClass: Susceptible sexual partners of persons who are HBsAg-positive should be offered post-exposure HBIG and hepatitis B vaccination; both should be initiated within 14 days of the last sexual contact

annotation.spannedText: Hepatitis B is relatively common in clients of sexual health services and vaccination should be offered to susceptible persons at the time of first attendance

classMention.mentionClass: Hepatitis B is relatively common in clients of sexual health services and vaccination should be offered to susceptible persons at the time of first attendance

annotation.spannedText: Susceptible, sexually active men who have sex with men should be vaccinated

classMention.mentionClass: Susceptible, sexually active men who have sex with men should be vaccinated

annotation.spannedText: Such persons should be offered testing for hepatitis B, and vaccination if appropriate

classMention.mentionClass: Such persons should be offered testing for hepatitis B, and vaccination if appropriate

annotation.spannedText: These patients should be given a larger than usual dose of hepatitis B vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: These patients should be given a larger than usual dose of hepatitis B vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Adult haemodialysis or pre-dialysis patients should be given either

classMention.mentionClass: Adult haemodialysis or pre-dialysis patients should be given either

annotation.spannedText: If seronegative for hepatitis B, solid organ transplant recipients should be vaccinated before transplantation as they may be at increased risk of infection from the transplanted organ

classMention.mentionClass: If seronegative for hepatitis B, solid organ transplant recipients should be vaccinated before transplantation as they may be at increased risk of infection from the transplanted organ

annotation.spannedText: Haematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients should be revaccinated following transplantation, due to the loss of immune memory that often follows the transplant procedure

classMention.mentionClass: Haematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients should be revaccinated following transplantation, due to the loss of immune memory that often follows the transplant procedure

annotation.spannedText: Persons who inject drugs should be tested, and be vaccinated if they have not previously been infected with HBV

classMention.mentionClass: Persons who inject drugs should be tested, and be vaccinated if they have not previously been infected with HBV

annotation.spannedText: persons with clotting disorders who receive blood product concentrates, persons with recurrent transfusion requirements, and persons with underlying immunocompromise68 have an elevated risk of hepatitis B virus infection, and should therefore be vaccinated

classMention.mentionClass: persons with clotting disorders who receive blood product concentrates, persons with recurrent transfusion requirements, and persons with underlying immunocompromise68 have an elevated risk of hepatitis B virus infection, and should therefore be vaccinated

annotation.spannedText: they should be offered the opportunity to be screened for hepatitis Bupon incarceration, as part of the preventive health program for blood-borne viruses, and vaccinated if susceptible

classMention.mentionClass: they should be offered the opportunity to be screened for hepatitis Bupon incarceration, as part of the preventive health program for blood-borne viruses, and vaccinated if susceptible

annotation.spannedText: it is recommended that all staff directly involved in patient care and/or the handling of human tissue, blood or body fluids should be vaccinated

classMention.mentionClass: it is recommended that all staff directly involved in patient care and/or the handling of human tissue, blood or body fluids should be vaccinated

annotation.spannedText: standard precautions against exposure to human tissue, blood or body fluids should be used as a matter of routine

classMention.mentionClass: standard precautions against exposure to human tissue, blood or body fluids should be used as a matter of routine

annotation.spannedText: If advice on risk is sought, the enquiry should be directed to the local public health authority

classMention.mentionClass: If advice on risk is sought, the enquiry should be directed to the local public health authority

annotation.spannedText: age-appropriate hepatitis B vaccination is recommended

classMention.mentionClass: age-appropriate hepatitis B vaccination is recommended

annotation.spannedText: Persons travelling to regions of intermediate or high endemicity, either long-term or for frequent short terms, or who are likely to undertake activities that increase their risks of exposure to HBV during travel, should be vaccinated

classMention.mentionClass: Persons travelling to regions of intermediate or high endemicity, either long-term or for frequent short terms, or who are likely to undertake activities that increase their risks of exposure to HBV during travel, should be vaccinated

annotation.spannedText: Combination hepatitis A/hepatitis B vaccines should be considered for susceptible persons in whom both hepatitis A and hepatitis B vaccines are recommended

classMention.mentionClass: Combination hepatitis A/hepatitis B vaccines should be considered for susceptible persons in whom both hepatitis A and hepatitis B vaccines are recommended

annotation.spannedText: The time for boosting in such persons should be decided by regular monitoring of anti-HBs levels at 6- to 12-monthly intervals

classMention.mentionClass: The time for boosting in such persons should be decided by regular monitoring of anti-HBs levels at 6- to 12-monthly intervals

annotation.spannedText: Testing also identifies those who are susceptible to HBV infection and, as such, should be offered vaccination if they continue to have a high exposure risk

classMention.mentionClass: Testing also identifies those who are susceptible to HBV infection and, as such, should be offered vaccination if they continue to have a high exposure risk

annotation.spannedText: Anti-HBs antibody and HBsAg levels should be measured in infants born to mothers with chronic hepatitis B infection 3 to 12 months after completing the primary vaccine course

annotation.spannedText: For these individuals, if adequate anti-HBs levels (≥10 mIU/mL) are not reached on serological testing 4 to 8 weeks after the 3rd dose, the possibility of HBV infection, including chronic HBV infection, should be investigated by testing for serological markers, including HBsAg and anti-HBc antibodies

classMention.mentionClass: For these individuals, if adequate anti-HBs levels (≥10 mIU/mL) are not reached on serological testing 4 to 8 weeks after the 3rd dose, the possibility of HBV infection, including chronic HBV infection, should be investigated by testing for serological markers, including HBsAg and anti-HBc antibodies

annotation.spannedText: In select cases in which hepatitis B infection is suspected, HBV nucleic acid testing may also be indicated, and expert advice regarding further management should be sought

classMention.mentionClass: In select cases in which hepatitis B infection is suspected, HBV nucleic acid testing may also be indicated, and expert advice regarding further management should be sought

annotation.spannedText: If there are no markers of HBV infection, the individual should be managed as a non-responder to hepatitis B vaccination

classMention.mentionClass: If there are no markers of HBV infection, the individual should be managed as a non-responder to hepatitis B vaccination

annotation.spannedText: If persons who are at significant risk of hepatitis B (such as healthcare workers) were not tested for anti-HBs within 4 to 8 weeks after completion of the documented primary course, they should still undergo serological testing to ensure immunity

classMention.mentionClass: If persons who are at significant risk of hepatitis B (such as healthcare workers) were not tested for anti-HBs within 4 to 8 weeks after completion of the documented primary course, they should still undergo serological testing to ensure immunity

annotation.spannedText: Persons with immune memory established from effective prior vaccination should respond to this booster dose

classMention.mentionClass: Persons with immune memory established from effective prior vaccination should respond to this booster dose

annotation.spannedText: Anti-HBs should be checked 4 weeks later, and if the anti-HBs level remains <10 mIU/mL, the possibility of HBV infection should be investigated

classMention.mentionClass: Anti-HBs should be checked 4 weeks later, and if the anti-HBs level remains <10 mIU/mL, the possibility of HBV infection should be investigated

annotation.spannedText: if excluded, the person should be managed as a non-responder to vaccination

classMention.mentionClass: if excluded, the person should be managed as a non-responder to vaccination

annotation.spannedText: Persistent non-responders should be informed that they should be considered not protected against hepatitis B and should minimise exposures

classMention.mentionClass: Persistent non-responders should be informed that they should be considered not protected against hepatitis B and should minimise exposures

annotation.spannedText: They should also be informed about the need for HBIG within 72 hours of parenteral or mucosal exposure to HBV

annotation.spannedText: Although various adverse events such as demyelinating diseases, Guillain-Barrï¿½ syndrome and arthritis have been reported, there is no evidence of a causal relationship with hepatitis B vaccination

classMention.mentionClass: Although various adverse events such as demyelinating diseases, Guillain-Barrï¿½ syndrome and arthritis have been reported, there is no evidence of a causal relationship with hepatitis B vaccination

classMention.mentionClass: Further instructions about the public health management of hepatitis B, including management of cases of acute hepatitis B and newly identified chronic hepatitis B, and their contacts, should be obtained from state/territory public health authorities
